Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Retention of Early Algebraic Understanding

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Discovery Research K-12 program (DRK-12) seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering and mathematics (STEM) by prek-12 students and teachers through research and development of innovative resources, models and tools. While national and state standards provide important benchmarks for algebra learning beginning in kindergarten, they do not provide rigorously tested models by which these algebra standards might be attained in elementary grades classrooms in ways that will ensure further mathematics achievement. This work will addresses this need by closely documenting the effectiveness of models and tools, developed in our previous work, for early algebra education

The proposed project will use a quasi-experimental design to explore students' knowledge of core algebraic concepts in middle grades (grade 6), one year after their completion of 3-year, grades 3-5 early algebra intervention. The project will also study the algebraic knowledge of a comparison group of students. The research questions are: (1) how well students who received a specific intervention retain their understanding of algebraic concepts in future years; and (2) whether and how the intervening year of regular classroom instruction in grade 6 influences the algebra understanding of both intervention and comparison students

POR.DRECONTENT:
Teaching and learning algebra is a critical goal in school mathematics. To prepare students for college and give them choices in STEM-related careers, it is now widely accepted that algebra education should begin informally in the elementary grades. However, innovative, research-based models of algebra education in elementary grades, as well as an understanding of how such models impact students’ algebra readiness in middle grades, are needed in order to fully implement this perspective.

This project extended a study of the impact of a 3-year, early algebra intervention in Grades 3–5 to a study of students’ algebra readiness in middle grades. In particular, it examined two primary issues one year after students’ participation in the elementary grades intervention ended: (1) how well intervention students retained their algebra understanding; and (2) how the intervening year of regular classroom instruction in Grade 6 influenced the algebra understanding of students who participated in the intervention as well as those who received only their regular instruction.

The core finding of this project was that, one year after completion of the early algebra intervention in elementary grades, students who received the intervention significantly outperformed those students who had received only regular math instruction on an algebra assessment designed to test understanding of core algebraic concepts and practices. The project found further that experimental students remained more successful than control students in engaging in core algebraic practices, such as justifying a conjecture, generalizing functional relationships and representing them in words and variables, and modelling linear problem situations with variable notation. Such results suggest that when students experience a broad, sustained approach to early algebra instruction, they are better positioned for success in algebra in middle grades.

In summary, this project addresses a critical national need by contributing evidence regarding the impact of an early algebra intervention on children’s algebra readiness in middle grades. In addition, findings of this project further strengthen the feasibility of the early algebra intervention being studied here. The significance of this feasibility is that the intervention offers instructional resources that Grades 3 – 5 teachers can use to implement early algebra instruction in their everyday classroom practice. In this sense, this project helps to provide practical solutions that can contribute to the development of a globally competitive algebra education.
